title: 111_hr3703
content:
The Act may be cited as the "White House Conference on Autism Act of 2009". The Congress acknowledges the rapid increase in Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) in the U.S., with rates rising from 1 in 10,000 to 1 in 150. The epidemic of autism continues to grow, with a new case diagnosed every 20 minutes. The financial burden of autism on the nation exceeds $35 billion annually. More children will be diagnosed with autism this year than with AIDS, diabetes, and cancer combined. Autism costs the Nation over $35 billion per year, a figure expected to significantly increase in the next decade. Autism is a life-changing condition that our Nation's communities are ill-equipped to handle. The long-term impact of this autism epidemic could potentially deprive our Nation of future talent. Autism spectrum disorders are an urgent societal concern, yet receive less than 5 percent of Federal funding for research. The Combating Autism Act of 2006 allocated nearly $1 billion for autism research, focusing on environmental factors, treatments, and early identification. A White House Conference on Autism aims to advance scientific study and analysis of cutting-edge treatments and services for autism. The Combating Autism Act of 2006 allocated funds for autism research, with a focus on environmental factors, treatments, and early identification. A White House Conference on Autism aims to advance scientific study and analysis of cutting-edge treatments and services for autism. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF THE CONFERENCE. The President must call the White House Conference on Autism by December 31, 2010, to make policy recommendations on combating autism in the US. The Secretaries of Health and Human Services, Education, and Housing will plan and conduct the Conference to find the underlying causes of autism. The Surgeon General will convene the White House Conference on Autism to galvanize a national effort to find the underlying causes of autism, identify solutions for autistic individuals and their families, and promote research on potential environmental triggers. The conference aims to bring together scientific experts, parents, and leaders in education and social services to address the lifelong challenges faced by autistic children and highlight innovative programs from both public and private sectors. The White House Conference on Autism aims to address challenges faced by autistic children and their families, highlight innovative programs from public and private sectors, and review existing legislation to improve the health and well-being of autistic individuals. SEC. 4. POLICY COMMITTEE; RELATED COMMITTEES. Established by June 30, 2009, the Policy Committee consists of 17 members appointed by the President and House Speaker. Members include officers, employees of the United States, and individuals experienced in addressing autism spectrum disorders. The Policy Committee, established in 2009, consists of 17 members appointed by the President and House Speaker. Members are selected by majority and minority leaders of the House and Senate, with special qualifications required. The Policy Committee, established in 2009, consists of 17 members appointed by the President and House Speaker. Members are selected by majority and minority leaders of the House and Senate, with special qualifications required. 50 percent of the members must be drawn from private industry, the nonprofit sector, or academia, with specific knowledge and expertise in autism intervention programs, educational needs, and housing needs for individuals with autism. The Policy Committee, established in 2009, consists of 17 members appointed by the President and House Speaker. Members are selected by majority and minority leaders of the House and Senate, with special qualifications required. 50 percent of the members must be drawn from private industry, the nonprofit sector, or academia, with specific knowledge and expertise in autism intervention programs, educational needs, housing needs, law enforcement training, and environmental factors related to autism development. The Committee acts by majority vote, with the Surgeon General serving as the Chairperson. The Policy Committee, chaired by the Surgeon General, is responsible for conducting Committee business, making recommendations for the timely convening of the Conference, and submitting a proposed agenda within 90 days of its first meeting. Meetings are initially called by the Cochairs and subsequently by the chairperson. The Policy Committee, chaired by the Surgeon General, is responsible for submitting a proposed agenda for the Conference within 90 days of its first meeting, making recommendations for delegates, determining the number of delegates, and establishing an executive committee to work with Conference delegates. SEC. 5. CONFERENCE DELEGATES. The Cochairs will gather delegates from various backgrounds in autism and neurodevelopmental disorders, including government representatives, professionals, laypeople, and members of the public affected by autism spectrum disorders in the United States. In administering this section, the Cochairs shall provide notice to all Policy Committee members of meetings, request cooperation from other federal departments, make proposed agendas available for public comment, and provide necessary background materials for delegates. The Cochairs are responsible for preparing background materials, employing additional personnel, and ensuring the proposed agenda is published in the Federal Register. They must also ensure that personnel are employed as needed without following certain provisions of the United States Code. The Conference agenda must be published in the Federal Register within 30 days of approval. Personnel must be balanced in viewpoints and appointed without political bias. Recommendations should be independent, not influenced by officials or special interests. Before the Conference, current statistical data on autism spectrum disorders in the US must be available. The Cochairs may accept gifts (cash or in kind) on behalf of the United States to support this Act. Records must be maintained by the Cochairs. The Cochairs can accept gifts for the Act, which must be recorded. Donors can specify the purpose of their gifts. Records must be kept on the sources, amounts, and uses of gifts, as well as the recipients of assistance and the amounts received. SEC. 7. REPORT OF THE CONFERENCE. The Policy Committee must prepare a preliminary report on the Conference within 100 days of adjournment, to be published in the Federal Register and sent to state chief executive officers. States must submit their views on the report within 45 days. A final report must be prepared within 6 months of adjournment, including state executives' views, and recommendations must be published in the Federal Register and sent to the President and Congress. The Policy Committee must prepare a report on the Conference within 100 days, to be published in the Federal Register and sent to state chief executive officers. States must submit their views within 45 days. A final report must be prepared within 6 months, including recommendations to be published in the Federal Register and sent to the President and Congress. SEC. 8. STATUS REPORTS.

The Surgeon General must prepare and publish a status report on the implementation of recommendations within 2 years of the Conference adjournment. The Comptroller General must prepare subsequent status reports every 5 years until all recommendations are achieved. These reports will be published in the Federal Register and transmitted to the President and Congress. The term "State" in this Act refers to several entities including States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, and the Northern Mariana Islands. Authorization of appropriations is also included in the Act. Authorization is granted for necessary funds to carry out the Act, with limitations on new spending authority. Funds appropriated and received as gifts are available for use, except as specified. Funds appropriated for the Act and gifts received shall be available for 1 year after the Conference adjourns. Unspent funds after this period will be returned to the Treasury, unless a trust fund is established for a future Autism Conference if the current one is not convened before December 31, 2010.
